review_title: Good plan B, but not much else.
pros:
Part-Time benefits are alright. Decent vacation/sick time, 401k is mediocre, no match, but is offered. The medical insurance is amazing though. 

Work requirements are a joke, and I often spend more time getting supervisor-sanctioned-sleep than working. This is dependent on your work area, but most are extremely lax. 

Job security is unmatched; short of killing someone you cannot lose your job.

Overtime is plentiful. Plenty of optional, and mandatory, overtime.
cons:
Limited chances for advancement. Due to the union structure you have to attain a high enough seniority to really get the good bids. This means potentially 10+ yrs of working as a 3hr to get a fulltime gig.

Training is non-existent. They try, but it lasts about a day before they throw you to the wolves. 

Overtime is plentiful. I don't actually like overtime, but there is a lot of it.

job_title: Seasonal Package Driver in Silverthorne, CO
pros: Good atmosphere, get the job done on your own.
cons: I left my job as a ski instructor to work here seasonally thinking I would make more money doing this during a pandemic.  I was wrong.  I was given the impression I would be getting something like 60 hours a week and only ended up getting maybe 25 hours a week, which is quite a significant difference.   I was layed off on Christmas day with no notification at all.  The following week I was called off work every single morning until I finally gave up.   I could have made money elsewhere but they had me thinking I would be employed through January.  They didnt care about me at all.  I would have been far better off if I stayed in the resort industry, because I have higher priority there than I did at UPS.  Maybe other locations are better but I had a terrible experience working at the Silverthorne, CO location.  I learned a very expensive lesson from this experience.

review_title: My overall experience was exceptional with all the knowledge and experience I can apply anywhere
pros:
•Great experience dealing with many employees and multiple management teams
•Learned how to be proficient in my computer skills (Microsoft, Excel, PowerPoint, and many other online websites) 
•Taught me how to be very well organized with paperwork and discipline with employees
•Learned how to be a great communicator with my employees and also management teams when it comes to meetings and presentations
•UPS has several different departments and moving parts. This experience has given me the knowledge on how larger companies work when it comes to the bigger picture. 
•In UPS you become very knowledgeable with OSHA and KETER regulations. (I have personally been audited my both throughout the years at UPS and have successfully passed with no findings)
•Gave me the experience with inbounds and outbounds of large companies
cons:
•I work a night shift schedule (9pm-6am)
•The UPS Worldport Hub is so large with around 12,000-15,000 people working just night shift alone. It is really hard to build personal relationships with all the employees and multiple management teams. Would really like a more interactive family type atmosphere.

pros:
UPS is a great company as far as their reputation for delivering goods on time 
Short hours that can turn into a full hours pay
weekly pay
No drug test
cons:
At my facility ( Atlanta SMART Hub in South Fulton) I would not recommend to anyone. 
As a pre-loader you are required to load up to 5 trucks at a time. With loading, requires you to scan each package that comes off the belt, mark the number of the location for the driver to see and then you will need to allocate each package to its truck, each package on the truck has to be put in numerical order and stacked to their standard. You are really in a race against time because the packages do NOT stop until the end of your shift. You will almost need to run from your truck back to the belt to make sure you grab your packages for your truck which can be very stressful keeping in mind all the steps you must take before moving out of your truck.
Most of the time the air vents do not work so you will need to constantly refill for water, remember the belt NEVER stops moving, so a 2 minute walk and push your belt back by 20 boxes that you have to sort through while others are still coming down. The managers are very rude and unprofessional most of the time, because most of them only know UPS and have no understanding that no one is their maid/butler and will talk down to you. You will receive no help until the drivers come in and at times they don't always show up on time so you are literally struggling your entire shift.
You do not get much training because the managers are always "busy" doing what seems like nothing. 
You will need to be there everyday prior to your clock in times because they will literally lock the doors and tell you they are not accepting anymore people-- if you are late and you manage to get in before the doors are locked, they will literally pull you from your belt and tell you to clock out.
Each day the workload is different, but Wednesdays is their busiest day and at times you can be working with over 60,000 boxes that will be divided amongst the other trucks, typically each truck will receive about 200-400 boxes, keep in mind you never have just one truck to load, so if you are not a fast worker, they will rush you and you will be stressed out your entire shift, just by the end of it to not even receive a thank you.. I can go on and on about the mishaps of this place, delivery jobs in general are stressful but if your work ethic is not appreciated do not give these companies your time.

review_title: OK for short term, but do not stay here too long. Many people leave after a year or less, for good reason.
pros:
- Good experience for CV if you just started working.
- Training is good, you get six weeks before you are dropped in a team. Makes it comfortable for new starters. (This could be negatively impacted since COVID)
- Options for specialized training and promotions if you are lucky.
- Relaxed atmosphere in the office (not relevant/applicable for the time being, still working from home).
- The work is quite easy and there is not much pressure (could be dependent on which team you end up in).
cons:
- The office building looks run-down, filthy, and abandoned. Thankfully we are still working from home.
- No facilities whatsoever: there is a pathetic break room, coffee is undrinkable and not free, only water is free, you have to bring your own cutlery, no options for food and no good nearby restaurants for lunch (only fast-food chains), the "quiet room" is uncomfortable and not really quiet at all.
- If you start out doing call centre work (most people start there) you will be unable to help most of the customers you get on the line. I do not know how it works for the other countries’ teams, but for the BE/NL team you have to constantly tell customers that they are calling the wrong department and that the department they need is only reachable via email (which they obviously don’t like to hear). The number of customers you can actually help is low.
- The systems this company uses for billing are incredibly outdated (you are using software that was last updated in the 80’s, 90’s, and early 2000’s, other companies have never heard of this software). This desperately needs an update.
- The company does not care about small customers, middle market customers, or their own staff. All that seems to matter is bending over backwards for huge companies like Amazon, Apple, etc.
- While there are some options for promotions, none of them are very interesting. 
- Working from home has been a disaster with everything being extremely slow (everything being both the company’s response and the technical side of things). Not only was the company late with sending everyone home compared to other similarly sized companies in Dublin, but management were also bragging about how good their response to the situation had been. You hear from acquaintances in other companies how they received a budget to buy equipment (desk, chair, etc.) to work comfortably from home, UPS did not even allow us to take the chairs we had in the office (that have not been used since March 2020). Not to mention they expect you to be microphone-capable on Zoom calls but do not supply you with a headset, even after 18 months of working from home…

pros: People; benefits; locations; operations; vacation
cons: Management; leadership (idiots); pay; opportunity

pros:
The benefits, hands down, are the only thing keeping me here at this point. For a part-time employee to have completely free healthcare is unheard of. Having weekends off is also a plus in my book. Your work environment is luck of the draw though. My shift (twilight) is laid-back and we all get along well. On the other hand, the morning shift, so I've been told by a friend, is an absolute nightmare; one supervisor used to be a military drill instructor and uses the same tactics on employees. So which atmosphere you are stuck with is complete luck.

Overall Pros:
-Benefits
-Good work environment (by chance)
-Weekends off
cons:
The elimination of "skilled positions", therefore getting rid of the skilled pay that used to accompany the position, is probably the worst decision that could've been made. I have worked there only since September of 2020, and have but put into a scanner position. Skipping plenty of people who have higher seniority than me. Why? Because I am a good worker. 

Although this may sound good, I have much more responsibility than many of my coworkers, more stress, getting absolutely buried in boxes every day because supervision refuses to get me any help when I need it. 

My day consists of sorting, scanning, and loading a trailer all at the same time, while being expected to keep the belts running continuously. If I wasn't refused help when I ask, I would have little to no complaints about this job. But something about being absolutely crushed every day while I see coworkers standing around laughing with each other just doesn't seem right; not to mention that we are making the same hourly rate. 

It has also come to my attention that myself, as well as several other coworkers, have not been being paid correctly. According to our local union contract, we should have been getting paid for holidays, as well as our 3.5 hour pay guarantee. We are in the process of sorting this out right now but it seems as if supervisors have absolutely no idea what is going on. We are currently being shorted in excess of $500 each. 

Overall cons:
-Lack of communication
-Uneven work distribution
-Lackadaisical supervision
-No skilled pay
-If you are a hard worker, you only get punished with stressful and overwhelming positions
-Not being paid correctly

pros: UPS drivers working with me were just amazing. After your orientation, they assign a driver who will train you in the field in many aspects of the job. There's a lot of fun while delivering packages, and once in awhile  making a few pick-ups. Every day is different.  Some times you have to go an extra mile to get the job done. It is a great job to lose a few pounds. You feel better physically and emotionally at the end of the day. I really appreciate it.
cons: If you aren't from New England you need to be ready for all winter related challenges: very cold temps, snow storms, black ice, slippery steps and sidewalks, you name it. It is more likely that as a seasonal driver for driver helper UPS will hire you to work during the always busy holiday season (Nov-Jan) so your supervisor expects you to be available to work overtime. And you know what, I really liked it.

review_title: COVID has you laid off? This should be your last resort.
pros: Benefits, Union protection, Tuition Reimbursement, no weekends (unless you opt for the Tues-Sat schedule vs the typical M-F), Overtime starts at 5+ hours (practically guaranteed on a Monday, usually on a Tuesday, W-F depends on package volume)
cons: No longer has a 401(k) match. Start time varies every day but typically starts later as the week progresses. Hours are capped around 25 per week unless you tell them you want more. You're nothing more than a piece of meat to reach their bottom line. Very physical job. *all about the bottom line*. High turnover rate. Supervisors break rules set by the Union (not touching packages/stealing work yet they sort ALL the time leading to us getting buried by boxes due to their lack of attention). Safety is preached but rarely practiced (packages falling at your feet inhibiting free movement, downplaying your injuries, overloading someone with too much work)

pros: Tuition assistance, maybe looks good on a resume.
cons:
Literally everything else. You work with people who are genuinely pretty awful. Management has created the ultimate toxic work environment there, and I really see no feasible way to reverse this. If you work in a small center like I do, you will most likely have all the responsibilities of a full time manager, with no extra pay. The health insurance is terrible. They automatically enrolled me into a tobacco policy, took out $200 from me before I realized it, then would not give it back. 

Unless you want to work here for the 5.5k a year tuition assistance, which is definitely nice, I would never recommend this to even my worst enemy. However, that assistance is guaranteed regardless of your degree I believe. That really is the only good benefit.

review_title: Good money but no time for a life or family
pros:
Great pay
Good benefits
Keep you in shape
Fun driving around and not having to deal with having to talk to the same people everyday
Get to enjoy being outside when the weather is nice
cons:
Long hours. About 50-60 in the off season and 60-70 from late November to February
Hard on your body, sometimes people die, like way too much
Cold weather and snow
Dangerous conditions
Rude people
Breathing exhaust and brake dust all day
Hot days. The back of the truck stays between about over 120, maybe even up to 150 for a good part of the summer
When it rains all day, you are out in it for about 10 to 12 hours
If the supervisors find any number of reasons not to like you they have a whole bank of protocol that they can bust you on if you don't follow even one step. Like grabbing a handrail while stepping onto the truck.
Kiss seeing your family goodbye because you will most likely wake up every morning, commute to work, work all day long from sun up till after sundown, then commute home, then it will most likely be sometime after 8pm that you get home. I had many days that I woke up at 6 to get to work, worked all day carrying 120lb packages up 4 flights of stairs, all while walking about 14 miles in the blistering summer or the freezing winter, just to get home after 12 or 1am.

review_title: UPS was not what I expected
pros: UPS is a large company with locations across the country. They are reliable and the business is generally solid and resistant to economic instability. Basically, it's a (small) paycheck.
cons:
I was temporarily furloughed from my airline job during the COVID-19 pandemic, and I expected that as a large transportation company working at UPS would be similar to the airline. I was wrong, and was very disappointed with my experience. (Disclaimer: I worked in a "small package center", not in the airline division of UPS. The airline operation may be better.)

I found that most employees at UPS very much did not want to be there, and it dragged down the entire culture. My immediate supervisor was miserable and generally wanted to be left alone. Full time supervisors in my building were expected to work 12-16 hours a day, 6 days a week. Due to the massive amounts of burn out everyone was generally in a bad mood and not tolerating of even minor mistakes. The upper management degraded and berated the supervisors on a daily basis. I literally saw a full-time supervisor go home crying after a meeting with the building/regional manager.

I was never trained to dispatch properly because it consisted solely of on-the-job training with my burnt out supervisor. We generally started work around 2330-midnight making the dispatch plan, but we only had until 1 or 2am to complete it before the system reset. This left us with 2.5 hours at best to complete the plan for almost 90 routes. My supervisor had been with UPS for over 20 years, and he was white knuckling it to get the job done in time without training me. There were a few times that he did try to train me, but considering I was brand new to the job I really had no idea what I was doing and we did not make timely progress. We could have come in earlier to spend more time training, but he still would have been expected to stay until at least noon and then come in again that night. Work life balance for is non-existent for full-time employees at UPS.

I also saw multiple part-time supervisors who wanted to be promoted get strung along for long periods of time. The woman who I replaced had been with UPS for 4 years, and was promised that she would be getting promoted to the be the Assistant (to the) Regional Manager. This never happened, and she was stuck on the box line where most the new supervisors start. When she saw that they were not going to give her the job they originally promised she started to train to become a driver. After a month of driving routes she was denied the permanent job, and had to go back to the part-time supervisor job on the box line. This was the last straw for her, and she left the company after nearly 5 years. She was an excellent employee and one of the few who kept a positive attitude despite the culture there. I am glad she got out, but it's a shame UPS treated her this way.

I was so fed up with working at UPS I actually put in my resignation prior to having a new job offer in hand. I figured that I'd rather be unemployed than continue to go into such a horrible work environment, and with peak coming I saw the writing on the wall that it would only get worse.
